trigger: The human <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene encodes a nuclear DNA - binding protein uniquely expressed in normal and neoplastic T-lineage lymphocytes .
The <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene encodes a putative transcription factor with affinity for a sequence motif occurring in a number of T-cell enhancers .
<extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA was originally found to be expressed in a T cell - specific fashion within a set of human and mouse cell lines .
In contrast , expression reportedly occurs in multiple nonlymphoid tissues during murine embryogenesis .
We have now raised a monoclonal antibody to document expression and biochemistry of the human <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein .
As expected , the <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein was detectable only in cell lines of T lineage .
Its expression was always restricted to the nucleus .

Immunohistochemistry on a panel of human tissues revealed that the <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein was found exclusively in thymocytes and in CD3+ T cells in peripheral lymphoid tissues .
Western blotting yielded a set of bands ranging from 25 kD to 55 kD , resulting from extensive alternative splicing .

The <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein was detectable in all samples of a set of 22 T-cell malignancies of various stages of maturation , but was absent from a large number of other hematologic neoplasms .

These observations imply a T cell - specific function for <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a notion corroborated by recent observations on <extra_id_0> Tcf-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> knock-out mice .
In addition , these results indicate that nuclear <extra_id_0> TCF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression can serve as a pan-T-lineage marker in the diagnosis of lymphoid malignancies .
